awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Engaging Students for Higher Retention and Building Stronger Foundations in Pre-Calculus Using the Flipped Model
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Norfolk State University seeks to raise the passing rate of pre-calculus by actively engaging students through implementation of the flipped classroom. As HBCUs produce the vast majority of African Americans entering the STEM workforce, these efforts will not only help this trend but also produce STEM graduates who are better prepared. These efforts will have a big impact on bolstering students' completion of STEM degrees, thus increasing the number of STEM majors entering graduate schools and the work place. In addition, this course structure will also be presented to secondary education professionals in workshops in the community.

The overall goals of the project are to increase the success rate in the STEM pre-calculus course and to deepen math connections to boost student learning. The specific goals are to: 1) increase the passing rate in pre-calculus; and 2) to provide a strong foundation in pre-calculus to bolster an increase in STEM major retention. Through the more hands-on approach via the flipped model, this project will strive to strengthen quantitative abilities, reasoning and critical thinking skills. The benefits to STEM education and NSU in achieving these goals include greater retention of undergraduate majors in STEM fields with a stronger foundation in STEM topics and development of autonomous learners which leads to a higher rate of students obtaining degrees and entering the workforce.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
During the fall of 2017, faculty in the Department of Mathematics at Norfolk State University (NSU) in the College of Science, Engineering, and Technology (CSET) implemented a Flipped Classroom Model of pedagogy designed to help students improve their progression through the math sequence that is required for STEM degree programs. The project was implemented in Pre-Calculus courses that were identified as high-risk or critical courses at NSU due to the number of students who earned a grade of D or F in the course or withdrew from the course (aka DFW). The overall goal was to increase the pass rate in Pre-Calculus to provide a strong foundation to increase retention in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM).

The overall findings from six (6) semesters of data collection on students’ grades indicated that students enrolled in the Flipped classes completed the Pre-Calculus course with higher grades than those in the non-Flipped classes. Specifically, students enrolled in the Flipped classes during fall 2017, spring 2019, fall 2019, and spring 2020 had statistically significant higher Pre-Calculus end-of-course grades than those enrolled in the non-Flipped classes during these semesters. The course grades during the spring 2018, fall 2018, and spring 2021 semesters were still higher for those in the Flipped classes, the differences were not statistically significant. Additional results analyzed from the pre- and post-surveys revealed that students enrolled in the Flipped classes also had greater self-efficacy, confidence, and resourcefulness in math and learning difficult subjects than students enrolled in the non-Flipped classes. Some of differences were found to be statistically significant over the course of the project. The results collected from fall 2020 and spring 2021 changed the dynamic of classroom pedagogy in part as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic required students and teachers alike to adjust to the online environment which could have impacted the SIs’ interactions with students in the Flipped classroom, and thereby impacted students’ grade and passing rates in the fall 2020 and spring 2021 semesters.

Several professional development workshops for faculty at Norfolk State University as well a workshop for math teachers at a local high school were conducted covering topics of active learning strategies, flipped classroom and the use of technology in the classroom. 

A YouTube channel was created hosting micro-lectures videos covering some topics in College Algebra as well as a repository of course topic worksheets.

The data was disseminated through presentations at math conferences as well as presentations a colloquiums.

 

The PI/Co-PI presented flipped learning topics at the College-wide meeting at opening session including different technologies, approaches and more student centered learning.

 

The Co-PI presented: Engaging Students for Higher Retention and Building Stronger Foundation in Pre-Calculus Using the Flipped Model , Contributed Paper Session – Flipped Classes: Implementation and Evaluation, JMM (Joint Math Meetings), San Diego, CA

 

The Co-PI presented Engaging Students for Higher Retention and Building Stronger Foundation in Pre-Calculus Using the Flipped Model , Contributed Poster Session, HBCU-UP TIP/CREST Meeting, Washington DC

 

The PI presented Flipping Pre-Calculus: The Good, The Bad and The Ugly at the MAA Section Meeting in November of 2019.

 

The PI presented Creating Interactive Classroom Using the Flipped Model with Supplemental Instruction at the Joint Mathematics Meetings 2020 in Denver Colorado.

 

The PI was a panelist in Cengage Learning Summer of Learning Webinar Series for Math and Science Faculty. The panel was entitled 5 Real Life Examples of Tools Used to Make and Deliver Videos. The PI discussed how she creates videos and uses them in the flipped classroom.

 

The PI was featured in the podcast entitled Next Up: Student Success.

 

The PI was featured in the Norfolk State University’s magazine BEHOLD: Volume 9     Issue 1.

 

The Co-PI published an article relating outcomes of this project: Brucal-Hallare, M. and Fernando, A.  “Leveling the Playing Field through Collaboration, Mastery, and Peer Interaction”, Lighthouse Almanac, Special issue on Critical Issues on the Education of Black Children, Vol 3, No 1, 2019

 

The PI presented Creating Interactive Classrooms Using the Flipped Model with Supplemental Instruction Flipped Again by COVID at Cal Poly Pomona Department of Mathematics and Statistics Colloquium series February 10, 2021.

 

The PI presented The Albert Turner Bharucha-Reid Lecture: From Riding the Bench to Leading the Team. Rewriting the Instructional Playbook for Pre-Calculus Using the Flipped Model at National Association of Mathematicians (NAM) Faculty Conference at on Research and Teaching excellence May 22, 2021

 

The PI presented Creating Interactive Classrooms Using the Flipped Model with Supplemental Instruction Flipped Again by COVID at Sonoma State University Department of Mathematics and Statistics Colloquium series September 1, 2021.

 

A paper was published relating outcomes of this project: Brucal-Hallare, M. and Fernando, A.  “Leveling the Playing Field through Collaboration, Mastery, and Peer Interaction”, Lighthouse Almanac, Special issue on Critical Issues on the Education of Black Children, Vol 3, No 1, 2019

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Anne M Fernando
